questions.text: During labor, the epidural anesthetic was accidentally injected into the peripheral cannula of the patient. The patient had a cardiac arrest and is being resuscitated. Which of the following would be considered correct in this patient's management?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The given condition is Local Anaesthetic Systemic Toxicity (LAST).
  • Local anesthetics like bupivacaine and ropivacaine work by blocking sodium channels in nerve membranes to prevent action potential conduction.
  • However, when they enter the systemic circulation in high doses, they also affect sodium channels in the heart and CNS.

questions.text: After neuraxial anesthesia with opioid adjuvant for a lower limb surgery, a patient can be expected to have all the following complications except
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Urinary incontinence is not expected to be a complication of neuraxial anesthesia with opioid adjuvant.

  • It is urinary retention and not incontinence that happens in Central neuraxial blockade. The incidence of urinary retention is most common in young males.
  • Urinary retention with neuraxial opioids is more common than after IV or IM administration of equivalent doses of the opioid.
  • The incidence of this side effect is not dose-dependent or related to systemic absorption of the opioid
  • Urinary retention is most likely due to the interaction of the opioid with opioid receptors located in the sacral spinal cord
  • This interaction promotes → inhibition of sacral parasympathetic nervous system outflow→ which causes detrusor muscle relaxation→ an increase in maximum bladder capacity → leading to urinary retention

Complications of Neuraxial Opioid Adjuvants

  • Respiratory Depression
  • Pruritus
  • Nausea and Vomiting
  • Urinary Retention
  • Sedation

Explanation of Other Options:

Depression of ventilation (Option A): The most serious side effect of neuraxial opioids is depression of ventilation, which may occur within minutes of administration or may be delayed for hours. This depression of ventilation most likely results from systemic absorption of the lipid-soluble opioid, although cephalad migration of opioids in the CSF may also be responsible.

Pruritus (Option B) induced by neuraxial opioids is likely due to cephalad migration of the opioid in CSF and subsequent interaction with opioid receptors in the trigeminal nucleus.

Central nervous system excitation (Option C): Tonic skeletal muscle rigidity resembling seizure activity is a well-known side effect of large IV doses of opioids, but this response is also sometimes observed after neuraxial administration.

questions.text: An eutectic mixture of local anaesthetics (EMLA cream) is sometimes used to numb the skin before attempting an intravenous access in pediatric patients. Which of the following local anesthetics is combined with lignocaine to produce this cream?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • EMLA (Eutectic Mixture of Local Anaesthetics) cream was formulated to overcome the obstacles presented by intact skin.
  • It consists of a mixture of 2.5% lidocaine and 2.5% prilocainebases in an emulsion.
  • Both are amide-type anesthetics, and when mixed in a 1:1 weight ratio, they form a eutectic mixture - a liquid at room temperature that enhances skin penetration.
  • Depth of analgesia (usually <0.5 cm), duration of action (usually <2 h), and amount of drug absorbed depend on application time, dermal blood flow, and total dose administered.
  • Typically, 1 to 2 g of creamis applied per 10-cm2 area of skin
  • Dermal analgesia, enough for inserting an intravenous catheter, requires about 1 h under an occlusive dressing

Used for topical dermal anesthesia, especially in children for:

  • IV cannulation
  • Minor procedures
  • Vaccinations

Local skin reactions such as

  • Pallor
  • Erythema
  • Alterations in temperature sensation
  • Oedema
  • Pruritus
  • Rashes are common after EMLA cream application
  • Plasma levels of lidocaine and prilocaine are below toxic levels, although methemoglobin concentrations reflecting the metabolism of prilocaine may be increased in children ≤ 3 months of age, reflecting immature reductase pathways.
  • Likewise, EMLA cream should not be used in those rare patients with congenital or idiopathic methemoglobinemia

Explanation of Other Options:

Bupivacaine (Option A): Too potent and cardiotoxic for topical use.Long-acting agent used for regional blocks (e.g., epidural, nerve blocks).High risk of systemic toxicity, especially cardiac arrhythmias, if absorbed. Not approved for topical application due to safety concerns.

Mepivacaine (Option C): Similar to Lidocaine but has a slightly longer duration and Less vasodilatory effect. Not part of any approved topical eutectic formulation. Poor evidence for efficacy through intact skin. Lacks the eutectic-forming property when combined with Lidocaine.

Ropivacaine (Option D): Long-acting, similar to Bupivacaine but less cardiotoxic. Used in regional anesthesia (e.g., epidurals, nerve blocks). Poor skin penetration and slow onset make it unsuitable for topical use. Not approved or studied extensively for dermal application.

questions.text: A patient has a history of an allergic reaction to a local anesthetic but does not recall the name. Which of the following local anesthetics will most likely be the cause of a true allergic reaction?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Procaine is most likely the cause of a true allergic reaction.

  • Esters of local anestheticsthat produce metabolites related to paraaminobenzoic acid are more likely than amide local anaesthetics, which are not metabolised to paraaminobenzoic acid, to evoke an allergic reaction. 
  • Of the given options, the only procaine is the Ester LA; all others are amides.

Allergic reactions can include:

  • Urticaria (hives)
  • Angioedema
  • Bronchospasm
  • Anaphylaxis (rare)

questions.text: The advantage of ropivacaine over bupivacaine is?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Ropivacaine has a higher therapeutic index and less cardiotoxicity as compared to bupivacaine.

  • This is because ropivacaine is the S (-) enantiomer of bupivacaine
  • The cardiotoxicity of bupivacaine is due to the R (+) isomer, which blocks the cardiac Na channels more avidly and dissociates more slowly (Option B ruled out)
  • Ropivacaine is less potent( Option D ruled out)
  • Epidural ropivacaine is 40 % less potent than bupivacaine
  • Ropivacaine has a shorter duration of action and produces less motor block than bupivacaine (Option A ruled out)

questions.text: Which of the following is true about transient neurological symptoms seen with local anesthetics?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Transient neurologic symptoms (TNS) manifest as moderate to severe pain in the lower back, buttocks, and posterior thighs that appears within 6 - 36 hoursafter complete recovery from uneventful single-shot spinal anesthesia (Option A)
  • The sensory and motor neurologic examinationis normal, and full recovery from symptoms usually occurs within 1 to 7days
  • The incidence of transient neurologic symptoms is greatest following the intrathecal injection of lidocaine(as high as 30%) (Option B ruled out)
  • The risk of transient neurologic symptoms associated with
    • Bupivacaine
    • Tetracaine is significantly less than Lidocaine
    • Mepivacaine
    • Prilocaine
  • Procaine: The incidence of transient neurologic symptoms is not altered by decreasing spinal lidocaine concentrations from 2% to 1% or 0.5%and is similar to the incidence of symptoms described with 5% lidocaine ( Option C ruled out)
  • The transient neurological symptoms seen with local anesthetics are not associated with the lithotomy position (Option D ruled out)

questions.text: The following local anesthetics are used for topical anaesthesia except?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Bupivacaine is not effective when applied topically because it is poorly absorbed through mucous membranes or intact skin, and its onset is too slow for topical use. Additionally, its higher systemic toxicity risk makes it unsafe for use where systemic absorption is uncontrolled.
  • Lidocaine, tetracaine, benzocaine, and dibucaine are the drugs most commonly used for topical anesthesia
  • Lidocaine and tetracaine are used as topical sprays before
    • Endotracheal intubation to blunt the cardiovascular responses
    • Before esophagoscopy and bronchoscopy for mucosal analgesia (Option A and D ruled out)
  • Lidocaine plus tetracaine combination is available as a peel → which can provide topical analgesia before superficial dermatological procedures
  • A lidocaine patchis available, which can be used → to relieve post-herpetic neuralgia
  • Benzocaine is commonly used for surface (topical) anaesthesia on skin and mucous membranes. ( Option B ruled out)
  • Cocaine can also be used to provide → topical anesthesia of the nose, nasopharynx, mouth, and throat
    • It has both analgesia and vasoconstricting properties, thereby decreasing surgical bleeding
  • EMLA (Eutectic Mixture of Local Anaesthetics) cream consists of a 1:1 mixture of 2.5% lidocaine and 2.5% prilocaine. EMLA can provide adequate dermal analgesia for procedures like:
    • Split-thickness skin-graft harvesting
    • Venepuncture
    • Laser removal of port wine stains
    • lithotripsy
    • circumcision

questions.text: For epidural anesthesia, the maximum dose of lidocaine without epinephrine is?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Maximum safe dose of lidocaine
    • 5 mg/kg without adrenaline (350 mg)
    • 7mg/ kg with adrenaline (500mg)
  • Maximum safe dose of bupivacaine
    • 2-3 mg/kg

choices.text: Addition of adjuvants like soda bicarb

questions.text: Factors affecting the onset of action of local anesthetics include all except?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Temperature is not a factor affecting the onset of action of local anesthetics.

  • The factors governing the onset of action of a local anesthetic are:
    • Concentration gradient
    • Mass degree of ionization
    • Solubility
  • The concentration gradient downis primarily a function of the quantity of local anesthetic injected → greater concentrations or larger volumes of a given drug will cause therapeutic concentrations to be achieved at the nerve more rapidly( Option D ruled out)
  • Ionizationis much more important.
    • Local anesthetics are buffers and will respond to changes in nascent hydrogen ion concentration by changing the ratio of unionized to ionized moieties
    • This equilibrium can be predicted by the pKa of the drug, as described by the Henderson-Hasselbach equation
    • The higher the pH→the more strongly the drug acts as a base; therefore, less of it will be unionized at normal body pH
    • It is the unionized, lipid-soluble moiety that can penetrate most rapidly the lipid-rich barriers protecting the axon( Option B ruled out)
  • Furthermore, it can be predicted that alkalinizationof the local anesthetic solution will result in a greater proportion of the local anesthetic molecules being in the unionized state, which can penetrate the nerve sheath ( Option A ruled out)

questions.text: A 35-year-old male undergoes a brachial plexus block for upper limb surgery. Postoperatively, he complains of severe, persistent neuropathic pain and numbness in the distribution of the block. Considering the choice of local anaesthetics used during the procedure, which of the following agents is most commonly responsible
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The given clinical scenario signifies neurotoxicity; lignocaine is the most neurotoxic local anaesthetic.

  • Among local anaesthetics, Neurotoxicity is maximum with
    • Lidocaine = Tetracaine>Bupivacaine >Ropivacaine
  • Lidocaine neurotoxicity may manifest as
    • Cauda equina syndrome following continuous spinal anaesthesia, pooling of the drug around the cauda equina, causing nerve damage
    • Transient neurological symptoms.The risk is further increased by the addition of vasoconstrictors→dysesthesia, burning pain, and aching in the lower extremities and buttocks→usually subside in 1 - 4 weeks
  • Chloroprocaine, another local anesthetic, had also been implicated in neurotoxicity following epiduralor spinal injections
  • This was largely due to the preservative, sodium bisulfite, and low pH
  • EDTA-containing chloroprocaine preparations were introduced, but they caused significant back pain(due to localized hypocalcaemia)
  • Lidocaine was associated with a significantly higher incidence of transient neurologic symptoms when compared to bupivacaine, prilocaine, or procaine( Option A, B, and C ruled out)

questions.text: A 35-year-old patient requires surgery on his forearm. Due to the nature of the procedure and the need for a bloodless field, the anesthesiologist plans to use intravenous regional anaesthesia (IVRA). Which of the following local anesthetics is most commonly used for IVRA?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Lidocainehas been the drug used most frequently for intravenous regional anesthesia
  • Prilocaine, mepivacaine, chloroprocaine, procaine, and etidocaine have also been used successfully
  • Intravenous regional anaesthesia or Bier's block involves the intravenous administration of a local anesthetic into a tourniquet-occluded limb
  • It is used to provide anesthesia for short surgical procedures (<90 minutes) on the limbs
  • Bupivacaine is not used for Bier's block.It is the most cardiotoxic local anesthetic. Accidental early inflation of the tourniquet →can lead to massive systemic doses of bupivacaine, resulting in →cardiac arrhythmias and cardiovascular collapse
  • Advantages:
    • Rapid onset of anesthesia.
    • Easy to perform.
    • Minimal systemic toxicity if the tourniquet is properly applied.
  • Disadvantages/Complications:
    • Risk of local anaesthetic systemic toxicity if the tourniquet fails or is released prematurely.
    • Limited to short procedures due to tourniquet tolerance.
    • Not suitable for limbs with vascular insufficiency.

Explanation of Other Options:

Mepivacaine(Option A): A local anesthetic with intermediate duration. It has been used for IVRA but less frequently than lidocaine due to a higher risk of toxicity when used intravenously.

Bupivacaine(Option C): Has a longer duration and higher potency but is generally avoided in IVRA due to the risk of severe cardiotoxicity if it leaks systemically during the procedure.

Procaine(Option D): An ester-type local anesthetic that was historically used for IVRA but is now rarely chosen due to its short duration, potential for allergic reactions, and less favorable pharmacokinetics.

questions.text: Which local anaesthetic is not to be given in a ring block of the finger?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Cocaine is not to be given in the ring block of the finger.

  • Cocaine produces vasoconstriction when applied topically and is a useful agent to reduce pain and epistaxis→ in nasal intubation in awake patients
  • However, it should NOT be injected around end arteries
    • Penile block
    • Ring block of finger
  • As it may cause arterial spasm→ischemia, necrosis, and gangrene

Lignocaine (Lidocaine)(Option A): Lignocaine is safe for ring blocks because it does not cause significant vasoconstriction and is widely used in digital anesthesia.

Prilocaine( Option B): Prilocaine is safe for finger blocks and commonly used in regional anesthesia, though high doses may rarely cause methemoglobinemia.

Procaine( Option D): Procaine is safe for use in ring blocks as it has minimal vasoconstrictive effects and a short duration of action.

questions.text: A 60-year-old diabetic patient presents with a chronic non-healing foot ulcer. The wound is painful, especially during dressing changes. To facilitate painless wound care, a topical local anaesthetic is considered. Which of the following local anesthetics is most appropriately used in this setting?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Benzocaine is a commonly used topical ester local anesthetic, especially suitable for:

  • Minor skin injuries
  • Ulcers
  • Mucosal surfaces
  • Painful wound dressings

It is rapid-acting, though not very deeply penetrating.

  • Benzocaineis a common ingredient in topical local anesthetic sprays for the management of wounds
  • However, it can cause dangerous levels of methemoglobinemia(MH)
  • So, it is NOT permitted for endoscopic procedures
  • Treatment of MH includes IV methylene blue(1-2 mg/kg of 1% solution over 5 min).

Explanation of Other Options:

Bupivacaine (Option A):

Long-acting amide LA, not used topically on wounds due to potential systemic toxicity and slow onset.

Chloroprocaine (Option B):

Short-acting ester, used in regional blocks, is not suitable for topical ulcer application.

Prilocaine (Option C) :

Amide-type LA, mainly used in EMLA cream (with lidocaine) for intact skin. Not ideal for open wounds due to the risk of methemoglobinemia.

choices.text: Crush injury to the hand and lacerated nerves.

questions.text: A 25-year-old male with a roadside accident underwent debridement and reduction of both fractured bones right forearm under axillary block. On the second postoperative day the patient complained of persistent numbness and paraesthesia in the right forearm and the hand. The commonest cause of this neurological dysfunction could be all the following except:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Systemic toxicity of local anaesthetics occur immediately or within hours
    Local anaesthesia systemic toxicity(LAST) is increased by
    • Hypoxia
    • Hypercapnia
    • Metabolic acidosis
    • Respiratory acidosis
    • Decreased hepatic function(cirrhosis, liver failure)
    • Decreased liver blood flow(CHF, B-blocker, H2 receptor blockers)
    • Renal failure
    • Advanced age
    • Genetically abnormal pseudocholinesterase

choices.text: Lidocaine is converted into a toxic metabolite due to its longer stay in the liver
Lidocaine concentration is initially higher in relatively well-perfused tissues such as the brain and heart
There is a sudden outburst of release of adrenaline, noradrenaline, and dopamine in the brain and heart
Histamine receptors in the rain and heart get suddenly activated in circulatory failure

questions.text: Cardiac or central nervous system toxicity may result when standard lidocaine doses are administered to patients with circulatory failure. This may be due to the following reason:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • CNS or CVS systemic toxicity may result when a standard lidocaine dose is administered to a patient with circulatory failure because its concentration is initially higher in relatively well-perfused tissue such as the brain & heart
  • And reduced cardiac output (in CHF) slows delivery of lidocaine(amide LA) to the liver, reducing their metabolism (to MEGX=mono ethyl glycine ylide), àprolonging Lidocaine's plasma half-life(Option A ruled out)
  • The toxicity of Lidocaine is due to its concentration in blood, NOT due to its toxic metabolite
  • MEGX can cause seizures in neonates

questions.text: From which of the following routes is the absorption of local anaesthetics maximum?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Intercostal absorption of local anaesthetic is maximum compared to others

  • Systemic absorption is directly proportional to the blood supply
  • Local Anaesthetic is absorbed very rapidly in intercostal block d/t close location of blood vessels around the nerve
  • The highest blood level of LA is achieved per volume of drug injected in intercostal block.
  • Sites of greatest absorption include:
  • Intrapleural >Intercostals >Pudendal >Caudal >Epidural >Brachial >Infiltration>Brachial Plexus Block( Option A, B and D ruled out)

questions.text: A 2-year-old child weighing 13 kg is scheduled for inguinal hernia repair. The calculated dose of 0.25% bupivacaine would be approximately_______ (mL):
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The calculated dose of 0.25% bupivacaine would be approximately 13 mL

The Armitage formula can be used for the calculation of caudal bupivacaine in a child with appropriate weight for his age.

  • 0.5 mL/kg for a lumbosacral block
  • 1 mL/kg for a thoracolumbar block
  • 1.25 mL/kg for a midthoracic block
  • For lower abdominal surgery (like inguinal hernia), we aim to block up to T10, which is a thoracolumbar block, and the dose is 1 mL/kg.
  • As the given weight of the child is 13 kg total dose would be 13kg*1ml/kg, which is equal to 13ml
  • 0.25% Bupivacaine up to a maximum of 20 ml

choices.text: Dibucaine is an ester-type local anaesthetic
A dibucaine number of 20 is normal
The dibucaine number represents the quantity of normal pseudocholinesterase

questions.text: Which of the following statements is correct?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

All the given statements about Dibucaine are incorrect

  • Dibucaine is a potent inhibitor of normal pseudocholinesterase, and that property is used in the dibucaine number test.
  • Dibucaine is an amide-type local anaesthetic that inhibits normal pseudocholinesterase by approximately 80%. A normal dibucaine number is typically around 80(Option A & B ruled out)
  • In patients who are heterozygous for atypical pseudocholinesterase, enzyme activity is inhibited by 40% to 60%.
  • In patients who are homozygous for atypical pseudocholinesterase, enzyme activity is inhibited by only 20%.
  • The dibucaine number is a qualitative assessment of pseudocholinesterase. (Option C ruled out)
  • Quantitative as well as qualitative determination of enzyme activity should be carried out in any patient who is suspected of having a pseudocholinesterase abnormality.

questions.text: Local infiltration of lignocaine and other local anaesthetic agents is less reliable for ankle block of an infected diabetic foot. This is because
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • In diabetic foot infections, especially those with cellulitis or abscess formation, the tissue environment becomes acidic due to infection, inflammation, and poor perfusion. This acidic pH affects local anaesthetic efficacy
  • Since local anesthetics are weak bases, they exist largely in the ionic form, making it difficult for them to cross the cell membrane, thus delaying their local anesthetic action.
  • Further, they become ionized when the local tissue is infected and the local pH is acidic.
  • Their action becomes unreliable.
  • The addition of sodium bicarbonate promotes the nonionized fraction of local anesthetics, promotinga more rapid onset of their action.
  • At physiological pH (7.4), there's a balance between ionized and non-ionized forms → good penetration and action.
  • At acidic pH (<7.4) (as seen in infected tissues), more of the anesthetic exists in the ionized form, which cannot cross the nerve membrane effectively → reduced anesthetic effect.

Explanation of Other Options:

Increased extracellular pH (Option A):

  • This would enhance local anesthetic effectiveness, not reduce it.
  • A higher pH would shift the drug toward the non-ionized form, making it easier to cross membranes.
  • Infections lower the pH, so this is the opposite of what happens.

Increased nonionized lidocaine concentration (Option B):

  • In acidic environments, the proportion of non-ionized (active) drug decreases, not increases.
  • This statement is not true in the context of infected tissue.
  • The non-ionized form is required to cross cell membranes and reach the intracellular site of action (sodium channels).
  • In an infection, more drug remains ionized, so its effectiveness is reduced.

Increased intracellular pH (Option D):

  • Local anesthetic efficacy is primarily influenced by the extracellular pH, not the intracellular pH.
  • Even if intracellular pH changes, it does not significantly impact the ability of the anesthetic to cross the membrane.
  • The barrier to entry lies in the acidic extracellular environment, which keeps the drug in its ionized form.

choices.text: A gamma > A delta > A alpha > B > C
A alpha > B > C > A gamma > A delta
B > C >A gamma > A delta > A alpha
C > B>A gamma > A delta > A alpha

questions.text: The correct order of susceptibility of nerve fibers to local anesthetic agents
questions.solution:
Explanation:

C > B>A gamma > A delta > A alpha is the correct order of susceptibility of nerve fibers to local anesthetic agents

  • Sensitivity of nerve fibers to inhibition by local anesthetics is influenced by axonal diameter, myelination, and other factors.
  • In comparing nerve fibers of the same type (myelinated versus unmyelinated), a smaller diameter associated with increased sensitivity to local anesthetics.
  • Thus, larger, faster-conducting Aα fibers are less sensitive to local anesthetics than smaller, slower-conducting Aδ fibers.
  • Larger myelinated fibers are less sensitive than smaller unmyelinated fibers.
  • On the other hand, small unmyelinated C fibers are relatively resistant to inhibition by local anesthetics as compared with larger myelinated fibers.
  • In a human peripheral nerve, the onset of local anesthetic inhibition generally follows this sequence: autonomi,c before sensory, before motor.

questions.text: While infiltrating local anesthetics, to prolong the duration of action, adrenaline is added. This should be avoided in
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Adrenaline should be avoided in parts having end-arterial supply, like the pinna, the nose, and the fingertips.

  • Addition of epinephrine less commonly phenylephrine-causes Vaso- vasoconstriction at the site of administration.
  • The consequent decreased absorption reduces the peak local anesthetic concentration in blood, facilitates neuronal uptake, enhances the quality of analgesia, prolongs the duration of analgesia, and limits toxic side effects.
  • However, they cannot be used in parts having end-arterial supply, as it will cause distal necrosis.

questions.text: Which of the following local anaesthetics is used as part of tumescent anaesthesia
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Lidocaine is used as part of tumescent anaesthesia.

  • The "tumescent" technique for liposuction is carried out via the subcutaneous infiltration of large volumes (5 or more liters) of solution containing highly diluted lidocaine (0.05% to 0.10%) with epinephrine (1:100,000).
  • The taut stretching of overlying blanched skin by the large volume of solution and epinephrine-induced vasoconstriction is the origin of the term tumescent technique.
  • The result is sufficient local anesthesia for the liposuction, virtually bloodless aspirates, and prolonged postoperative analgesia.
  • Lidocaine is the most commonly used local anesthetic in tumescent anesthesia.
  • Has a rapid onset and intermediate duration.
  • Its metabolism by the liver and widespread familiarity among clinicians make it a preferred agent.

Explanation of Other Options:

Bupivacaine (Option B)

Bupivacaine is avoided in tumescent anaesthesia because of its high risk of cardiotoxicity when used in large volumes.

Ropivacaine ( Option C)

Ropivacaine is not typically used in tumescent anaesthesia as its safety in large-volume infiltration is not well established.

Prilocaine ( Option D)

Prilocaine is not preferred for tumescent anaesthesia due to the risk of methemoglobinemia at high doses.

questions.text:
Regarding local anesthetics, which of the following are true:
A. Potency is related to lipid solubility
B. Protein binding is inversely proportional to duration of action
C. They are weak acids
D. They are less ionized below their pKa
E. Speed of onset is increased in the unionized state
questions.solution:
Explanation:

A: Potency is related to lipid solubility, where the more lipid soluble, the more potent the drug.

B: Duration of action is directly proportional to protein binding, as the drug bound to protein represents a store of drug.

C: Local anesthetics are weak bases that must be in the unionized state to penetrate the phospholipid membrane into the cytoplasm, where they become ionized and block sodium channel activity.

D: Speed of onset is determined by the pKa, as this determines the state of ionization. The pKa is the pH at which there is equilibrium between ionized and unionized states. For weak bases such as local anesthetic agents, they are more ionized below their pKa; thus, the higher the pKa, the more ionized a drug will be at physiological pH.

E: Because it is the unionized form that is active, the lower the pKa, the faster the speed of onset.

questions.text: When asked to describe the symptoms of her allergy to a local anaesthetic that a 26-year-old female had at the dentist's office, the patient described a feeling of lightheadedness, palpitations, and flushing. This reaction is most likely caused by
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The above-mentioned symptoms are not typical of a true allergic reaction, but more consistent with the systemic effects of epinephrine, a common additive in local anesthetics used to prolong duration and reduce bleeding.

  • Dentists usually add epinephrine to the local anaesthetic to decrease the bleeding associated with the dental procedure.
  • If any epinephrine gets access to the vascular system, it can cause transient tachycardia and hypertension that the patient may describe as palpitations, flushing, and dizziness.
  • If labelled as an allergic reaction, it may limit anaesthetic options for the patient in the future.

Explanation of Other Options:

Methylparaben reaction (Option A): Methylparaben is a preservative used in some multi-dose vials of local anesthetics.Can cause delayed hypersensitivity reactions, typically skin-related (rash, itching).Not associated with flushing, palpitations, or light-headedness.

Vasovagal reaction (Option B): Characterized by Bradycardia, Hypotension, Pallor, Nausea, Syncope. Not associated with palpitations or flushing. This patient's tachycardia and flushing make a vasovagal reaction unlikely.

Para-aminobenzoic acid (PABA) allergy (Option C): PABA is a breakdown product of ester-type local anesthetics (like procaine). Can cause true allergic reactions,such as Urticaria, Bronchospasm, Anaphylaxis. Patient received local anesthetic at a dental office- usually amide-type, not ester.

questions.text: An 18-year-old woman in the active stage of labor requests an epidural anesthetic. Immediately following injection of 2 mL and 5 mL test doses of 1.5% lidocaine with 1:200,000 epinephrine through the epidural catheter, the patient complains of lip numbness and becomes very apprehensive. Her heart rate has increased from 85 to 105 beats/min. What is your presumptive diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Based on the clinical scenario, the most probable diagnosis is Intravascular injection of local anaesthetic.

  • Circumoral numbness and apprehension immediately following administration of lidocaine suggest an intravascular injection of local anesthetic.
  • Abrupt tachycardia strongly suggests intravascular injection of epinephrine.
  • Management: Stop further injection immediately and reassess catheter placement.

Allergic reaction (Option A)

  • True allergic reactions to local anesthetics are rare, especially to amides like lidocaine.
  • Allergic reactions often involve:
    • Rash, urticaria
    • Bronchospasm
    • Hypotension or anaphylaxis
  • No signs of allergy (skin or respiratory involvement) in this scenario.

Local anesthetic systemic toxicity (LAST) (Option C)

  • LAST usually occurs with large or rapid IV doses of local anesthetics.
  • Presents with:
    • CNS excitation: seizures, tinnitus, confusion → followed by depression
    • Cardiac signs: bradycardia, arrhythmias, cardiac arrest
  • In this case, no seizure or cardiovascular collapse was reported.
  • This is an early sign of potential toxicity, but the actual dose was only a test dose, so not yet toxic.

questions.text: A 28-year-old female, a case of severe preeclampsia, has been administered magnesium sulphate in the labour room, following which a decision has been taken to opt for an emergency LSCS due to fetal bradycardia. All drug doses have to be reduced after administering magnesium sulphate, except
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Magnesium enhances the effects of other CNS depressants and neuromuscular blocking agents; 30–50% of the normal dose of non-depolarising relaxants should be used to maintain neuromuscular blockade in the presence of magnesium sulfate.
  • Acute administration of magnesium sulfate before the use of suxamethonium appears to prevent potassium release and may reduce the incidence and severity of muscle pains.
  • It does not affect local anaesthetic doses.
  • Magnesium does not potentiate lignocaine's primary action (sodium channel blockade).
  • In fact, it may have a synergistic analgesic effect, allowing for the same or even lower doses of lignocaine in regional anesthesia or pain management
  • It does not significantly depress CNS or cardiovascular function in combination, so dose adjustment is unnecessary.

Explanation of Other Options:

Rocuronium (Option B) (non-depolarizing NMJ blocker): Magnesium clearly potentiates its effect, shortening onset and prolonging duration-dose must be reduced

Succinylcholine (Option A )(depolarizing NMJ blocker): Magnesium may attenuate fasciculations and not significantly potentiate blockade; some sources even suggest possible mild antagonism . Nonetheless, current clinical consensus leans towards err on the side of caution and dose adjustment in some settings.

Desflurane (Option C) (volatile anesthetic): Magnesium has CNS depressant and vasodilatory effects, which enhance the action of volatile agents-dose reduction is required

questions.text: Which of the following properties of epidurally administered local anaesthetics determines the extent to which epinephrine will prolong the duration of blockade?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The lipid solubility property of epidurally administered local anaesthetics determines the extent to which epinephrine will prolong the duration of blockade

  • Epinephrine is primarily added to local anaesthetics to:
    • Check the IV placement of an epidural catheter
    • Decrease the vascular uptake of local anaesthetics
    • Increase the intensity and duration of the block
  • By producing vasoconstriction of the epidural blood vessels, vascular uptake of the local anaesthetic is reduced, allowing more of the drug to enter the nervous tissue.
  • The more lipid soluble the local anaesthetic, the less effect epinephrine has (e.g., lidocaine is prolonged much more than bupivacaine when epinephrine is added to the local anaesthetic)

Explanation of Other Options:

Molecular Weight (Option A)

  • Molecular weight affects diffusion, not the duration of action or interaction with epinephrine.
  • It plays a minor role in the pharmacokinetics of local anesthetics in clinical practice.

pKa (Option C)

  • The pKa of a local anaesthetic affects the onset of action, not how epinephrine influences duration.
  • LAs with pKa closer to physiological pH (e.g., lidocaine) have more non-ionised form → faster onset.
  • But pKa does not influence how much epinephrine prolongs the block.

Concentration (Option D)

  • While concentration affects the intensity and volume of blockade, it doesn’t predict how much epinephrine will prolong the effect.
  • Epinephrine works by vasoconstriction, reducing drug absorption into circulation, unrelated to drug concentration.

questions.text: American Society of Regional Anaesthesia (ASRA) guidelines for the treatment of local anaesthetic systemic toxicity (LAST) for cardiac arrhythmias include the use of Intralipid and the avoidance of all of the following drugs except
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • During resuscitation for local anaesthetic systemic toxicity (LAST), the ASRA 2020 guidelines recommend intralipid infusion as the cornerstone therapy.
  • Simultaneously, several other cardiovascular drugs should be avoided, but low-dose epinephrine is permitted.
  • Low-dose epinephrine helps support blood pressure and cardiac output in patients with cardiovascular collapse due to LAST.

Current (2012) ASRA guidelines for LAST for a 70-kg patient with cardiovascular collapse include the following:

  • Get help.
  • Initial focus-airway management, seizure suppression, and consideration for cardiopulmonary bypass.
  • Management of cardiac arrhythmias-basic and advanced cardiac life support, the avoidance of vasopressin, calcium channel blockers, β-blockers, or local anaesthetics.( Option A, B and C ruled out)
  • Epinephrine doses should be reduced.

questions.text: A 30-year-old pregnant woman is scheduled for an elective cesarean section under epidural anaesthesia. The attending anesthesiologist chooses a local anaesthetic based on rapid metabolism in both maternal and fetal plasma. Which anaesthetic offers the most rapid metabolism and minimal fetal exposure?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Chloroprocaine offers the most rapid metabolism and minimal fetal exposure.

Features:

  • Ester-type local anaesthetic.
  • Metabolised within <1 minute by both plasma and hepatic esterases, obstetric use, it offers rapid onset, short duration (0.5-1 h), and minimal placental transfer due to extremely fast degradation, even in cases of fetal acidosis.
  • Ideal for urgent anaesthetic extension, ensuring infants avoid significant drug exposure.

Explanation of Other Options:

Lidocaine (Option A):

  • Amide-type, intermediate onset and duration.
  • Notably crosses the placenta with a fetal/maternal ratio of ~0.5–0.9Metabolized in the liver (half-life ~1.5-2 h)
  • Moderate fetal exposure-not the fastest metabolizer.

Bupivacaine (Option B):

  • Long-acting amide with slow hepatic metabolism (half-life ~3.5 h)
  • Fetal/maternal ratio ~0.3-0.56, but remains in fetal plasma for hours
  • Not suitable when rapid fetal clearance is desired.

Ropivacaine (Option C):

  • Long-acting amide, similar to bupivacaine but metabolised more rapidly.
  • Still crosses placenta; half-life ~1.6-6 h
  • Not as fast-metabolised as chloroprocaine.
